text: Patient: I think the, the trial’s a little more targeted. The chemo is more general. Doctor: Ehhhh -- Well it’s – uh. The immunotherapy’s targeted to the immune system, but it’s not targeted to your cancer. Again, it, too, is like chemotherapy, praying and hoping that it’s gonna attack your cancer. Patient: Uh-huh. Okay. Doctor: It definitely has less side effects than chemotherapy. It just has more risk because if it attacks you, then you can get into trouble faster. Patient: My hair will fall out again? Doctor: Nope. (Pause) Patient: Okay will it get curlier? Doctor: It got curlier because the old chemotherapy’s outta your system. Patient: Yeah. (Pause5sec) Family Member: Well, so, if I was your dad, what would you do? Let him have to decide? Doctor: Yeah. I, um, I don’t know – I’ve never made a decision for ya. Family Member: Right. Doctor: You know, the issue is sort of your sense of what you do to your children, brother, what you want to do. You’re physically well enough. You, you know, if you can think about those things, I think a clinical trial makes a lot of sense.

text: Patient: Side effects? Doctor: You could have had the radiation. This is intravenous infusion. You know what this is, is the stuff that Marie Curie discovered all those years ago in the late eighteen hundreds. That’s what she discovered to try to treat cancer and now we actually use to treat cancer. Patient: Oh, wow! Doctor: Yeah. It’s just in smaller doses. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: So, I think the fact you’ve had radiation before is not, you know, an issue. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Where it would have been an issue is if you’d gotten so much that you didn’t have any bone marrow reserve left, you know, like you’re perpetually having a low red blood cell count and need a blood transfusion but that’s not you so it’s something we consider but definitely not something we have to fuss about with you. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Okay. Just so you know cost wise, you know, no one ponies up money to just do this because, you know, you’re used to having the high ticket items for Zytiga and Xtandi but this is about fifteen thousand a dose so insurance has to clear it because that’s just the drug cost not everything else. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, in that sense you might see a bigger invoice, you know, at the end of it but most insurance companies cover it in whole

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: don’t drink water, don’t drink tea, don’t drink coffee, don’t drink juice, don’t drink milk, don’t drink anything. After dinner, just done. One, that will allow you to sleep because I think your prostate is acting up, it’s too big which means it’s blocking the way of the pee and then what happens is you pee but there’s stuff left over but your body doesn’t know it until just a little bit more accumulates in there and also your bladder is like oh, I was this full and now I’m this full, okay, I got to pee again and when you’re laying down you pee a lot easier because then your whole body is trying to recalibrate and what’s happening. So, at that point you got to pee some more. So, if you give it less reason to pee which means you don’t have enough fluid on board then you won’t pee because there’s not fluid to put through. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you do me a favor and do that. I’ll work on getting your CAT scan and your bone scan set up and then we’ll figure out the next step. My thinking is that it probably - I’m going to shoot for the ah vaccine because once that’s done we don’t go back to it and then we just sort of put that and say done and then we move on to the other stuff. What do you think of that? Because if that sounds okay what takes forever is insurance Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: so if you’re kind of conceptually okay with that then I’m going to have J____, you know J____ who is our nurse, if you don’t know J____, you’re gonna know J____ in a minute. Patient: Is that the one that took the… Doctor: You had K____ Patient: K__ left. Doctor: but K____ left me so J____ is now working with me but actually J____ and I have worked together in the fifteen years I’ve been here. So, she was my original nurse that did a whole bunch of stuff but she’s always stayed on this team so she is also a very you know excellent prostate expert so she is going to help with trying to figure out if your insurance will say yes because it’s all great that you and I agree but if your insurance says, what are you kidding me, then we have to take that option off the table and just move on. Sound okay? Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: It’s kind of a lot today isn’t it? Patient: I want the best of what the best is for.

text: Family Member: or is he still gonna feel fatigued and miserable. Doctor: You should feel better. I know it’s counterintuitive. Like wait, you’re poisoning me and you’re telling me I would feel better. I think you feel bad because your cancer is not controlled, Patient: Okay. Doctor: you know, and some people could have a PSA at three thousand and feel better than you. Some people could have a PSA of thirty and feel worse than you. I don’t really care what the number is. I do know that your cancer isn’t treated. So, when you have untreated cancer you just don’t feel good. Patient: Okay, because I like to work outside and do stuff Doctor: Um hum Patient: and I do that but then it seems like the next day, does that have a part to it or no? Family Member: If he overdoes it on one day. Doctor: Oh, of course. Oh, everybody does that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Everybody does that not just you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know there’s two philosophies with that which is like oh, if it’s good day I’m gonna max it out so I can veg out the next day and I have some other patients that will just like pace themselves like I know it’s a good day but I don’t want to pay the price the next day so I’ll just moderate myself and then it’s more even. So, it’s really your preference. Some people would just be like I’d rather have one good day out of three rather than my the eh days.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Looking at the first scan we did when we first started. The scan we did after enzalutamide. So then we’re back at sort of like this. It sort of looks like we’re staying on. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So things are still growing at a slow to moderate pace, I’d say. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh so yeah I, I, I’m always concerned about that but I don’t think it’s reflective of making it grow more. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now we have seen folks you know stop the testosterone and PSA goes back down. Some of that elevation is related to, to stimulate production. Patient: Right. Doctor: So you know we’d like to see where, where we go with that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh in terms of once we reboot to be well again. The uh the problem we face is you know looking at the trials there are sort of two levels of looking at what’s available next.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
